repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Adds support for C++11 [forwarding references](https://isocpp.org/blog/2012/11/universal-references-in-c11-scott-meyers). Please see my comment [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3821#discussion_r487540605) for more details about the scope of this PR.

Would greatly appreciate input on the high level approach here -- I hope the changes aren't too intrusive.

Closes #3814.

comment_data.body: Is this OK? I was afraid that this would be too intrusive, but it might become necessary if Cython wants to support rvalue references more broadly going forward

I'm using inheritance here purely for code reuse. An rvalue reference does not have an "is-a" relationship with lvalue reference. Open to other suggestions here, and ditto with  CppRvalueReferenceType/CReferenceType.

The main issue would be if there was a `visit_CReferenceDeclaratorNode` in a transform somewhere and your new node accidentally got caught by it. The other way would be to move the implementation to a common base class that's shared between `CppRvalueReferenceType` and `CReferenceType`.

This section looks to happen on both template and non-template functions? That makes me wonder if it should be in the code that deals specifically with template functions? (I could be wrong about this though).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5763,6 +5763,17 @@ def analyse_c_function_call(self, env):
         else:
             overloaded_entry = None
 
+        # For any argument/parameter pair A/P, if P is a forwarding reference,
+        # use lvalue-reference-to-A for deduction in place of A when the
+        # function call argument is an lvalue. See:
+        # https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/template_argument_deduction#Deduction_from_a_function_call
+        arg_types = [arg.type for arg in args]
+        if func_type.is_cfunction:

comment_data.body: I know templates are the "hard" bit of this, but it'd probably be good to check that it can handle non-template functions too.

Ah apologies -- there may be some confusion here. The intended scope of this PR is handling forwarding references specifically, and not the more general "rvalue references". I should have been clear about the distinction between the two in the description:  

A forwarding reference is defined as a [function parameter of a function template declared as rvalue reference to cv-unqualified type template parameter of that same function template](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/reference#Forwarding_references)

Examples:

```c++
template <typename T>
void foo(T&& x);  // x is a forwarding reference

void foo(int&& x);  // x is not a forwarding reference

template <typename T>
void foo(const T&& x);  // x is not a forwarding reference (not const-volatile-unqualified)

template <typename T>
void foo(vector<T>&& x);  // x is not a forwarding reference (not an rvalue reference to the template parameter)
```

So forwarding references by definition appear only in templated functions, and only as input parameters (not return values). They represent a subset of the different contexts in which rvalue references appear in C++.

Forwarding references are different from rvalue references in that they can bind to _both_ lvalues and rvalues. In conjunction with `std::forward`, they are used to "maintain" the lvalue-ness or rvalue-ness of the argument when dispatching to other functions. 

I understand this is a bit of a "backwards" approach, and that adding true support for rvalue references as function parameters and return types in Cython is probably more useful. I implemented this specifically to support https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3790.

All this being said, I'd be more than happy to look into adding support for `&&` more generally. Although I'd prefer to do that in a separate PR if that's alright.

Fair enough - thanks for the clarification. Llimiting it to a small change needed to solve your specific problem makes sense.

It might be worth making sure that users get a helpful error message if they try to do something that isn't currently supported. Put a small file with some of the obvious uses in `tests/errors` (plus a comment to remove the file in future if/when full support is added). Right now this might appear to compile a lot of code, and then not generate sensible results.
A common base class sounds good. I'll go with that
Will do!
Done.
I moved it down to what I think is the part that deals only with templates. Does that look right?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5763,6 +5763,17 @@ def analyse_c_function_call(self, env):

+        # For any argument/parameter pair A/P, if P is a forwarding reference,

+        # function call argument is an lvalue. See:
+        # https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/template_argument_deduction#Deduction_from_a_function_call
+        arg_types = [arg.type for arg in args]
+        if func_type.is_cfunction:

comment_data.body: Added a few tests.

Sorry for introducing yet another `_make_move*` result into the mix, but I don't understand the naming here.

This was how I implemented the approach @scoder mentions in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3821#issuecomment-693925316.

Open to other suggestions here

I wonder if this should generate `std::move` rather than `__PYX_MOVE_IF_POSSIBLE`?

`__PYX_MOVE_IF_POSSIBLE` was designed as an improvement for C++11 that didn't break C++98 code.
If the type is an r-value reference then it's definitely going to require C++11 and so there's no need to generate the "compatible" version (which won't work here anyway).
I changed to use `std::move`.
Is this not something that could be handled in `_make_move_result_rhs()`? It feels wrong to have two separate methods where we generate the `move`.
This all fits into one line now. There is no reason for it to occupy seven.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5770,8 +5773,24 @@ def analyse_c_function_call(self, env):
             else:
                 alternatives = overloaded_entry.all_alternatives()
 
+            # For any argument/parameter pair A/P, if P is a forwarding reference,
+            # use lvalue-reference-to-A for deduction in place of A when the
+            # function call argument is an lvalue. See:
+            # https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/template_argument_deduction#Deduction_from_a_function_call
+            arg_types = [arg.type for arg in args]
+            if func_type.is_cfunction:
+                for i, formal_arg in enumerate(func_type.args):
+                    if formal_arg.is_forwarding_reference():
+                        if self.args[i].is_lvalue():
+                            arg_types[i] = PyrexTypes.c_ref_type(arg_types[i])
+
             entry = PyrexTypes.best_match(
-                [arg.type for arg in args], alternatives, self.pos, env, args)
+                arg_types,
+                alternatives,
+                self.pos,
+                env,
+                args
+            )

comment_data.body:
Probably ok, although it might have an impact on the error reporting if users accidentally write `a && b` instead of `a and b` in a C-ish context (certainly happened to me more than once). Might be worth special-casing that in the parser to really give a good error message. The same applies to `||` then. Doesn't have to be part of this PR, though.
Note that this wouldn't fit into the error test that you wrote. Should be more something like `errors/c_mistakes.pyx` or so.
Isn't it more of a `_CReferenceDeclaratorBaseNode`? Or does it have a semantic meaning all by itself?

comment_data.body: It looks like it doesn't hurt to generate the `__PYX_…` macro for this, which really just translates to `std::move()`. My comment is more about the place where this C++ code snippet is generated in our code, and having two places that essentially do the same thing, just slightly differently, is always a source of future trouble.

The reason I argued for generating `std::move` is the `__PYX_MOVE_IF_SUPPORTED` macro doesn't generate the move if it doesn't detect a suitable compiler (currently it doesn't detect MSVC correctly...). That's fine when `std::move` is mainly an optimization (better to assume no C++11 support and not break people's code), but here move is necessary for it to work at all.

comment_data.body:
Oh, then that's why it's called `…_IF_SUPPORTED`. :-D (Some things become so much more obvious when you actually look at them.)

Yeah, that's a good point. I'd still like to keep the code generation in one place, though. The conditions for this seem to overlap, and I think it's better to add an option like `optional=False`, than to generate the `std::move()` call in two different places using a short-cut.
Marking resolved :)

comment_data.body: I've attempted to localize the code generation to _make_move_result_rhs using an `optional` kwarg. Hopefully it looks OK.

The problem here is that because of the check for `self.type.is_cpp_class` above, this won't call `std::move()` on fundamental types, which we definitely need to allow.

We should safely be able to remove the check for `self.type.is_cpp_class`. I brought this up [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3821#issuecomment-693409883).
comment_data.diff_hunk:

-        if not optional:
-            self.has_temp_moved = True
-            return "std::move({0})".format(result)
         if (self.is_temp and allow_move and
                 self.type.is_cpp_class and not self.type.is_reference):
             self.has_temp_moved = True
-            return "__PYX_STD_MOVE_IF_SUPPORTED({0})".format(result)
+            return "{}({})".format(

comment_data.body: I'm ok with either adding `… or is_rvalue_reference` or, preferably, always trying to `std::move()` whatever we have in C++ mode. The latter seems a more "intrusive" but probably also more correct solution. Especially in C++, user declared types might not always be exactly what Cython sees of them. Doing something that "usually doesn't hurt" but "might work better in some cases" seems a good path to walk.

                 self.type.is_cpp_class and not self.type.is_reference):
             self.has_temp_moved = True
-            return "__PYX_STD_MOVE_IF_SUPPORTED({0})".format(result)
+            return "{}({})".format(

I'd agree this would be a good solution.

I [struggled for a while](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3821#issuecomment-693626570) to get a handle to the scope from inside this function or its callers in a straightforward way. I'm also not sure I understand what https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3821#issuecomment-693635460 would look like. Any suggestions?

comment_data.body: There doesn't seem to be a test for this.

Sorry to add to the back-and-forth on this, but I think `optional=False` is a better choice here. Using `force_move=False` means that I have to doubly opt-in to get what I call. That seems wrong. When I say `move_result_rhs()`, it should generate a `move()` for the argument, unless that's really not possible (i.e. in non-C++ mode). I would even prefer an explicit (C?-)compile time error if I request a `move()` but it cannot be done. If I want it to be best-effort, then _that_ should be visible in the place where it's used. I should not have to jump through two levels of method calls to understand that the code that I'm looking at only sometimes does what it says.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -503,21 +503,25 @@ def result(self):
         else:
             return self.calculate_result_code()
 
-    def _make_move_result_rhs(self, result, allow_move=True):
-        if (self.is_temp and allow_move and
-                self.type.is_cpp_class and not self.type.is_reference):
+    def _make_move_result_rhs(self, result, allow_move=True, force_move=False):
+        if force_move or (

comment_data.body:
No worries. That makes sense -- I changed it to `optional=False`. What do you think about removing the `allow_move` kwarg here? I think the combinationn of `allow_move` and `optional` make the function hard to reason about. I propose instead of:

```
condition = ....
return _make_move_result_rhs(result, allow_move=condition, optional=optional)
```

We have:

```
condition = ...
return _make_move_result_rhs(result, optional=optional) if condition else result
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -503,21 +503,25 @@ def result(self):
         else:
             return self.calculate_result_code()
 
-    def _make_move_result_rhs(self, result, allow_move=True):
-        if (self.is_temp and allow_move and
-                self.type.is_cpp_class and not self.type.is_reference):
+    def _make_move_result_rhs(self, result, allow_move=True, force_move=False):
+        if force_move or (

comment_data.body: Added `e_cpp_references.pyx` to test both lvalue and rvalue references for this.

commit.message: Localize the forwarding reference handling a bit more
Fix line numbers in error tests
Add and pass test for rvalue reference arg binding
Only parse rvalue references in C++ mode
Make rvalue ref tests cpp mode

commit.message: Merge branch 'add-forwarding-references' of github.com:shwina/cython into add-forwarding-references

Join parser code for reference and forward reference since both do essentially the same thing.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: [RFC] Add support for forwarding references
